faq.question: What types of student accommodation are available?
faq.answer: There are several types of student accommodation available, including halls of residence, shared flats, and private rented accommodation.

faq.question: What are the benefits of living in university accommodation?
faq.answer: Living in university accommodation can be a great way to meet new people and make friends, as well as being close to campus and having easy access to university facilities and support services.

faq.question: How do I apply for university accommodation?
faq.answer: You will need to apply for university accommodation through your chosen university's accommodation office. This is usually done online, and you will need to provide information about your course and personal preferences.

faq.question: Can I choose who I live with?

faq.question: What is the cost of student accommodation?

faq.question: What if I have a disability or medical condition that affects my accommodation needs?
faq.answer: Universities have support services available to students with disabilities or medical conditions that affect their accommodation needs. Contact your chosen university's accommodation office to discuss your requirements.

faq.question: Is accommodation guaranteed for first-year students?

faq.question: What should I pack for student accommodation?

faq.question: Can I stay in university accommodation during holidays?

faq.question: What happens if I don't like my accommodation?

faq.question: Can I bring guests to my accommodation?

faq.question: Can I cook in my accommodation?

faq.question: Can I smoke in my accommodation?

faq.question: What happens if I don't pay my accommodation fees?

faq.question: Can I decorate my accommodation?
faq.answer: Most universities have rules about decorating student accommodation, so you should check with your chosen university's accommodation office for their policy. In general, decorations should be non-permanent and not damage the property.

faq.question: What should I do if I have a problem with my accommodation?

faq.question: What are the benefits of living in student accommodation?
faq.answer: Living in student accommodation can be a great way to make friends, integrate into university life, and have access to on-campus resources and support. It can also be a convenient and cost-effective option for students who live far from the university.

faq.question: What is council tax?
faq.answer: Council tax is a tax that is levied on domestic properties in the UK. The money collected from council tax is used to fund local services such as rubbish collection, road maintenance, and police and fire services.

faq.question: Do I need to pay council tax if I am a student?
faq.answer: Full-time students are exempt from paying council tax in the UK. However, if you are living in a household that includes non-students, they may be required to pay council tax.

faq.question: What is included in household bills?
faq.answer: Household bills typically include electricity, gas, water, and internet. Depending on your accommodation, you may also need to pay for TV license, contents insurance, and phone line rental.

faq.question: How are household bills usually paid?
faq.answer: Household bills can be paid in a number of ways, including direct debit, standing order, or by using a prepayment meter. Many utility providers also offer online billing and payment options.

faq.question: What happens if I don't pay my household bills?
faq.answer: If you don't pay your household bills on time, you may incur late payment charges and your services may be disconnected. In some cases, your credit score may also be affected.

faq.question: How can I reduce my household bills?
faq.answer: There are a number of ways to reduce your household bills, including switching to a cheaper energy provider, using energy-efficient appliances, and being mindful of your usage. You can also look for deals and discounts, and consider sharing bills with your flatmates.

faq.question: How do I set up household bills for a shared house?
faq.answer: If you are living in a shared house, you will need to decide how you want to split the bills and who will be responsible for paying them. You can set up a joint account or use a bill-splitting app to make the process easier.

faq.question: What is a TV license?
faq.answer: A TV license is a legal requirement in the UK if you watch or record live TV. The money collected from TV licenses is used to fund the BBC and its services.

faq.question: Do I need a TV license if I only watch Netflix or YouTube?
faq.answer: If you only watch on-demand services like Netflix or YouTube, you do not need a TV license. However, if you watch or record live TV, you will need a TV license.

faq.question: How do I get a refund for overpaid council tax?
faq.answer: If you have overpaid your council tax, you can apply for a refund from your local council. You will need to provide evidence of your overpayment, such as a copy of your bill or bank statement.

faq.question: What should I do if I am having trouble paying my household bills?
faq.answer: If you are struggling to pay your household bills, you should contact your utility providers and council as soon as possible to discuss your options. You may be able to set up a payment plan or apply for financial assistance.

faq.question: Can I change energy providers if I am renting a property?
faq.answer: If you are renting a property, you can still switch energy providers. However, you should check your tenancy agreement first to make sure there are no restrictions on switching.

faq.question: What is a meter reading?
faq.answer: A meter reading is a measurement of your energy usage, taken from your gas or electricity meter. It is used to calculate your bill.

faq.question: How often should I take a meter reading?
faq.answer: You should take a meter reading at least once a month, but it is recommended to take them more frequently if you are on a prepayment meter or if you are trying to monitor your energy usage.

faq.question: How do I know if I am eligible for a discount on my council tax?
faq.answer: There are a number of discounts available for council tax, including a single person discount and a student discount. You can check with your local council to see if you are eligible.

faq.question: What is the difference between a fixed-rate and variable-rate energy tariff?
faq.answer: A fixed-rate energy tariff means that your energy prices will not change for a set period of time, usually 12 months. A variable-rate tariff means that your energy prices may change at any time, depending on the energy market.

faq.question: How do I make a complaint about my energy provider?
faq.answer: If you have a complaint about your energy provider, you should first contact them directly to try to resolve the issue. If you are not satisfied with their response, you can escalate the complaint to the Energy Ombudsman.

faq.question: What should I do if I think my council tax band is wrong?
faq.answer: If you think your council tax band is wrong, you can appeal to the Valuation Office Agency (VOA). You should provide evidence to support your appeal, such as recent sales of similar properties in your area.

faq.question: How do I cancel my TV license?
faq.answer: If you no longer need a TV license, you can cancel it online or by phone. You will need to provide your TV license number and the reason for cancellation.

faq.question: What is the Warm Home Discount?
faq.answer: The Warm Home Discount is a scheme that provides eligible households with a discount on their energy bills during the winter months. The scheme is run by energy companies and is aimed at helping vulnerable households and those on low incomes.

faq.question: What rights do I have as a tenant in the UK?
faq.answer: As a tenant in the UK, you have the right to live in a property that is safe and in a good state of repair. You also have the right to challenge excessive charges and to be protected from unfair eviction.

faq.question: What is a tenancy agreement?
faq.answer: A tenancy agreement is a legal contract between a landlord and a tenant. It sets out the terms and conditions of the tenancy, including the rent, the length of the tenancy, and the responsibilities of both the landlord and the tenant.

faq.question: What is a deposit and how much can my landlord charge me?
faq.answer: A deposit is a sum of money paid by the tenant to the landlord as security against damage to the property or non-payment of rent. In the UK, the maximum amount that a landlord can charge for a deposit is usually the equivalent of five weeks' rent.

faq.question: What should I do if my landlord is not fulfilling their responsibilities?
faq.answer: If your landlord is not fulfilling their responsibilities, you should first try to resolve the issue by talking to them. If this does not work, you can contact your local council or a tenants' rights organization for advice and support.

faq.question: Can my landlord evict me without a reason?
faq.answer: No, your landlord cannot evict you without a reason. They must have a valid reason, such as non-payment of rent or breach of the tenancy agreement, and they must follow the proper legal procedures for eviction.

faq.question: What is a guarantor and do I need one?
faq.answer: A guarantor is someone who agrees to pay your rent if you are unable to do so. Landlords often require a guarantor if you are a student or if you have a low income or poor credit history.

faq.question: Can my landlord enter my property without my permission?
faq.answer: No, your landlord cannot enter your property without your permission. They must give you reasonable notice and have a valid reason for entering, such as to carry out repairs or inspections.

faq.question: What is the difference between a fixed-term and a periodic tenancy?
faq.answer: A fixed-term tenancy is a tenancy agreement that lasts for a specific period of time, such as six months or a year. A periodic tenancy is a tenancy agreement that continues on a rolling basis, usually from month to month or week to week.

faq.question: What should I do if I am experiencing harassment from my landlord or other tenants?
faq.answer: If you are experiencing harassment from your landlord or other tenants, you should report the issue to your local council or the police. You may also want to seek legal advice or contact a tenants' rights organization for support.

faq.question: How do I find accommodation as a student?
faq.answer: Your university should have a housing office or a student services office that can help you find accommodation. You can also look for accommodation on private rental websites or through estate agents.

faq.question: What documents do I need to provide to rent a property?
faq.answer: You will typically need to provide identification documents such as your passport or driving license, proof of income, and a reference from a previous landlord or your university.

faq.question: What is a tenancy agreement?
faq.answer: A tenancy agreement is a legal document that outlines the terms and conditions of your tenancy. It typically covers details such as the rental amount, the length of the tenancy, and the responsibilities of both the tenant and the landlord.

faq.question: What is a security deposit?
faq.answer: A security deposit is a sum of money that a tenant pays to the landlord at the beginning of the tenancy. It is held as security against any damage to the property or unpaid rent, and will be returned at the end of the tenancy if there are no issues.

faq.question: What are my responsibilities as a tenant?
faq.answer: As a tenant, you are responsible for paying your rent on time, keeping the property clean and well-maintained, and informing your landlord of any necessary repairs or maintenance. You must also comply with the terms of your tenancy agreement.

faq.question: What should I do if I have a problem with my landlord or my accommodation?
faq.answer: You should first try to resolve the issue with your landlord or the accommodation provider. If this does not work, you can seek help from your university's housing office or a tenants' rights organization.

faq.question: Can my landlord increase my rent during my tenancy?
faq.answer: If you have a fixed-term tenancy agreement, your landlord cannot increase your rent until the end of the tenancy. If you have a periodic tenancy (e.g. month-to-month), your landlord can increase the rent, but must provide you with proper notice.

faq.question: What is the process for ending a tenancy?
faq.answer: The process for ending a tenancy will depend on the terms of your tenancy agreement. You will typically need to provide notice to your landlord, and may need to pay any outstanding rent or damages before you can leave the property.

faq.question: What should I do if I am struggling to pay my rent?
faq.answer: If you are struggling to pay your rent, you should speak to your landlord or accommodation provider as soon as possible.
